did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Curtis Cook Zuni Pueblo storytelling collection
1964-2005
did.physdesc: 2 photographic prints : black and white ; various sizes.

corpname.part: Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of field recordings, photographs, and notes by linguist Curtis Cook, who learned the Zuni language and documented the stories of elderly Zuni speakers while undertaking a translation of the Bible into the Zuni language during the 1960s and 1970s. Sound recordings (1964-1967) include narratives told by Zuni storytellers Longkeena Nash and Tom Ideque and others; recordings of children reading high school reports in English; and Curtis Cook reciting the gospel acccording to St. Mark, and other recordings. Photographs (1964-1972) include pictures of some of the Zuni speakers and storytellers who aided Cook in learning the Zuni language; landscapes at and near Zuni; adobe brick making and daily occupations at Zuni; photographs documenting the Zuni entry of dancers and musicians at the Gallup Intertribal Ceremonial in 1965; Zuni children; Zuni artwork, including jewelry and pottery. Manuscripts include Zuni stories and translation exercises in Zuni, and some interlineal translations in English of Zuni recordings from the Doris Duke collection. Cook submitted notes describing his photographs and his work at Zuni in 2004. On February 14, 2005, Curtis Cook met with staff of the American Folklife Center to discuss this collection and his work in Zuni. An audio recording of this meeting is included in the collection.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

subject.part: Zuni Indians--New Mexico--Zuni--Social life and customs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The manuscript material is the first series in this collection, in Boxes 1-3 (Folders 1-53). For the most part, the manuscripts are arranged chronologically by date of creation.
The second series contains the sound recordings, SR01-SR06. The original reel-to-reel tape boxes were retained to preserve the notes on the box labels and are stored in Box 4.

The final series consists of the graphic images. Slides 1-196 and photographs ph1-ph20 are arranged in numerical order according to the sequential numbers assigned by the donor, Curtis Cook, and are stored in Box 5 of the collection. Captions and notes for the images, as assigned by Curtis Cook, are also stored in Box 5.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of sound recordings may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
Collection is open for research. Access to recordings may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Curtis Cook Zuni Pueblo storytelling collection (AFC 2004/010), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Notes
bioghist.p: In 1964, Curtis Cook worked with the Zuni Pueblo as a member of Wycliffe Bible Translators, an international organization that translates the Bible into local languages. Cook was given the Zuni name, "Chummali," or locust, because he actively conversed with everyone in the village. A year after he arrived, the written alphabet for the Zuni language was developed and a few small pamphlets and literacy manuals were published to assist the Zuni in creating a written record in their own language.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of field recordings, photographs, and notes by linguist Curtis Cook, who learned the Zuni language and documented the stories of elderly Zuni speakers while undertaking a translation of the Bible into the Zuni language during the 1960s and 1970s. Sound recordings (1964-1967) include narratives told by Zuni storytellers Longkeena Nash and Tom Ideque and others; recordings of children reading high school reports in English; and Curtis Cook reciting the gospel acccording to St. Mark, and other recordings. Photographs (1964-1972) include pictures of some of the Zuni speakers and storytellers who aided Cook in learning the Zuni language; landscapes at and near Zuni; adobe brick making and daily occupations at Zuni; photographs documenting the Zuni entry of dancers and musicians at the Gallup Intertribal Ceremonial in 1965; Zuni children; Zuni artwork, including jewelry and pottery. Manuscripts include Zuni stories and translation exercises in Zuni, and some interlineal translations in English of Zuni recordings from the Doris Duke collection. Cook submitted notes describing his photographs and his work at Zuni in 2004. On February 14, 2005, Curtis Cook met with staff of the American Folklife Center to discuss this collection and his work in Zuni, an audio recording of this meeting is included in the collection.

did.unittitle: Finding Aid

Notes Clarifying Orthographic Representation and Interpretation,
February 1965.

scopecontent.p: A summary of the linguistic committee consultation written by Curtis Cook.

did.unittitle:
A Proposed Zuni Orthography,
September 1965.

scopecontent.p: Explanation of reasons for orthographic choices listing phonetic sounds of the Zuni alphabet. Submitted by Curtis Cook to the Summer Institue of Linguistics for review.

did.unittitle:
The Zuni Lanuguage: A Phonemic Statement,
September 4, 1965.

scopecontent.p: Technical paper describing the sound and syllable system of the Zuni language. Prerequisite to the development of practical orthography. Submitted by Curtis Cook for approval by the Summer Institute of Linguistics.

did.unittitle:
Inventory of Zuni Sounds and Practical Orthographic Representations,
1965-1966

scopecontent.p: Submitted by Curtis Cook and approved in September 1966 at Branch Conference.

did.unittitle:
Letter of Acceptance from Dr. Irvine Davis. Linguistic consultant for the Summer Institute of Linguistics,
September 13, 1965.

Zuni Language Features,
1970

scopecontent.p: Zuni onomatopoeia and Zuni pronouns and verb classes prepared by Curtis Cook for use in Zuni language classes.

did.unittitle:
God An Bena:We K'okshi. Mark Ts'ina:Washkowa. (Gospel of Mark),
Circa 1970.

scopecontent.p: First Draft of the Gospel of Mark in Zuni. Handwritten in phonetic transcription with partial interlinear English translation and with edits.

did.unittitle:
God An Bena:We K'okshi. Mark Ts'ina:washkowa,
1970

scopecontent.p: The Gospel of Mark translated by Mr. And Mrs. Curtis Cook with Rex Chimoni, Lorenzo Chavez, Floyd Owaleon, and Johnny Cheama. Published by Wycliffe Bible Translators, Inc., Eastlake, Colorado.

did.unittitle:
Suski,
1971

scopecontent.p: Coyote Stories in Zuni and in English as told by Lorenzo Chavez. Transcribed and translated by Curtis Cook. Published by the Summer Institute of Linguistics, Zuni, New Mexico.

did.unittitle:
Coyote and Crow. Coyote and Locust,
Circa 1971.

scopecontent.p: A free translation by Curtis Cook of two of the three Zuni folk tales in Suski.

did.unittitle:
Ho'n A:Wan Delapna:We. (Our Stories),
1972

scopecontent.p: Collection of self-authored stories by Zuni students in grades 5-8 at the Zuni Christian Reformed Mission School. Published by Gallup-Mckinley County Schools, Gallup, New Mexico.

did.unittitle:
Zuni Literacy Teacher's Guide,
November 1972.

scopecontent.p: A set of literacy lesson plans illustrating Zuni alphabet, word-building charts, and reading drills by Curtis Cook. Published by Gallup-Mckinley County Schools Follow Through, Gallup, New Mexico.

did.unittitle:
A Glossary of Common Zuni Terms,
1973

scopecontent.p: English to Zuni translation of common vocabulary words edited by Wilfred Eriacho. Published by The Pueblo of Zuni, Zuni, New Mexico.

did.unittitle:
Kya:k Hołi. (Long Ago),
1974

scopecontent.p: Zuni transcription of three old stories by Lokina and Diwla. Transcribed by Wilfred Eriacho. Edited by Wilfred Eriacho and Curtis Cook. Published by The Pueblo of Zuni, Zuni, New Mexico.

did.unittitle:
Zuni Tribal Oath of Office,
Circa 1975.

scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes and typed oath in Zuni translated into Zuni by Curtis Cook.

did.unittitle:
A:shiwi A:wan An'ułłanakya Haydoshnan:we,
Circa 1975.

scopecontent.p: (Zuni Tribal Constitution Articles I, II, and III.) English and Zuni versions of the Zuni tribal consitution.

did.unittitle:
Nucleus and Margin of Zuni Clause Types,
May 15, 1975.

scopecontent.p: A booklet containing this technical article by Curtis Cook published in Linguistics by Mouton and Co., The Hague, The Netherlands.

did.unittitle:
Ulohnan ibałdok'yan ihap, kop leyadinna? (When the world is about to end, what will happen?),
1976

scopecontent.p: A booklet translated by Curtis Cook relating to events surrounding a recent earthquake to the book of Matthew, Chapter 24. Published by Wycliffe Bible Translators, Inc. Eastlake, Colorado.

did.unittitle:
Acts. Kwa'hol God an Duda'tsi:kwe Lewunapkowa. (What God's disciples did),
1978

scopecontent.p: A translation of the Book of Acts by Curtis Cook with Rex Chimoni, Lorenzo Chavez. Published by The World Home Bible League, South Holland, Illinois, and The Canadian Home Bible League, Weston, Ontario.

scopecontent.p: Handwritten first draft of the Gospel of John in the Zuni language by Curtis Cook. Notebook 5 contains Chapters 11:22-16:11.

The Zuni Language,

Back Translation (Zuni to English) of the final draft of the Gospel of John, Chapters 1-4,

did.unittitle: Series III: Photographs

scopecontent.p: Image descriptions provided by Curtis Cook.

did.unittitle:
The first old man I met at Zuni (name unknown),
September, 1963

scopecontent.p: This was on my first visit to Zuni on the way back from my last year of training in linguistics at the University of Oklahoma. Upon arriving at Zuni, I began to walk around the village, and came across this old man. The old man's daughter stepped out of her house when I stopped to visit with him. She spoke English, so I asked her how to tell the old man "Hello." Then I asked her to ask him to let me take his picture. He consented, so I took the picture, then asked his daughter how to say "thank you" in Zuni. I took the picture, and said, "Elahkwa." I was speaking Zuni.

did.unittitle:
Rex Natewa, my first language helper,
1965

scopecontent.p: He was the native pastor of the Christian Reformed Mission at Zuni.

did.unittitle:
Rex Natewa, my first language helper,
1965

scopecontent.p: Rex was a literalist, when it came to teaching me to speak Zuni. I asked him how I would tell someone, "I'm glad (that) you came," after they had visited me. His response in Zuni was two separate declarative statements: "I'm glad" and "You came". Neither statement had anything to do with the other. Rex passed away in 1965. I was at his bedside, when he died.

did.unittitle:
Longkeena Nash, the storyteller,
1967

scopecontent.p: Photo taken in front of my home at Zuni in 1967.

did.unittitle:
Longkeena Nash, the storyteller,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: Longkeena would sometimes stop by after going to the trading post.

did.unittitle:
Longkeena,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: Almost all of my early language learning was in visits such as this with old men. Consequently, I learned an older dialect of Zuni; so much so that a high schooler in the literacy class I taught in summer school commented: "Cook, he talks like an old man."

did.unittitle:
Na:dusa (Lorenzo Chavez), my primary language helper,
1965-1973

Na:dusa (Lorenzo Chavez),
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: Lorenzo was believed to be in his late 90's when I first met him.

did.unittitle:
Na:dusa (Lorenzo Chavez),
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: My times with Lorenzo, were among the richest and most memorable of my entire fifteen years at Zuni.

did.unittitle:
Old man Lashhina Hu'tsi, Owaleon Nash,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: Old man Lashhina Hu'tsi, Owaleon Nash, believed to have been over 100 years old in this picture.

did.unittitle:
Old man Lashhina Hu'tsi, Owaleon Nash,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: In a session with Owaleon Nash, I was trying to find an equivalent term for the Biblical concept of "repentance." I told him in Zuni that "repentance" was what you do when you are walking one direction on your road of life (an appropriate metaphor in Zuni for one's personal conduct), and you decide that you're not walking the right way; so you "change your road" (i.e., "you change your behavior"). After giving the idea some thought, he said "How can I change my road? I'm a Zuni."

did.unittitle:
At work once again with Lorenzo Chavez,
1965-1977

Lorenzo and I spent many hours at his small house at Ojo Caliente, a farming village 13 miles west of Zuni village,
1965-1973

Lorenzo Chavez,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: Lorenzo was always sharp, and had an exceptional memory. His input into the translation work was extremely reliable, and he was so highly respected among the people that it was very much to my advantage to have used him as my primary language helper.

did.unittitle:
For several years, when we lived in a small house behind the Vanderwagen Trading Post, I did my work in a small camping trailer next to the house,
1965-1977

In my new study at Blackrock, 5 miles east of Zuni village, where we lived from 1972 to 1977,
1972-1973

In my study,
1972-1973

scopecontent.p: In my study, I maintained a very rigorous schedule, working 9-10 hours a day, doing something in which I took great delight; but I also sought to balance desk work with visiting in the village, affording me opportunities to hear and to speak the language in different contexts.

did.unittitle:
At my desk,
1965-1973

scopecontent.p: At my desk – using several commentaries, and English translations of the Bible, as well as the original Greek text, I prepared the first draft to be checked for accuracy with a Zuni speaker later.

did.unittitle:
At my desk,
1965-1973

scopecontent.p: At my desk – the translation was checked periodically by an experienced translation consultant from the Summer Institute of Linguistics. The checking sessions were conducted with a native speaker present, and the consultants concluded that the Zuni translation was of highest quality, in terms of both its faithfulness to the original text and accuracy, communicating the right concepts to native speakers.

did.unittitle:
Peter Neha,
1965-1977

scopecontent.p: I spent a only a short time in my translation work with Peter Neha, father of fourteen children. He was kept busy with his livelihood: making adobe bricks (see slides 141-149). (NOTE) Unfortunately, I do not have photographs of several others who helped me with the translation from time to time. Among them, Rex Chimoni, who was native pastor at the Christian Reformed Mission after the passing of Rex Natewa. Mr. Chimoni became a very good friend, and was an excellent language helper. Other helpers were: Arthur and Floyd Owaleon, and Lincoln Harker, Spencer Nashboo, and John Cheama.

Zuni welcoming sign at the northern reservation boundary,
1963-1978

Zuni mesas in the distance,
1963-1972

Mesas to the south of the sacred mountain, Dowa Yalanne ("corn mountain"),

Aerial view of Blackrock, site of the Indian Health Service hospital and a small number of residences 5 miles east of Zuni village,

Rainbow over the north end of Dowa Yalanne, with remnants of a stone wall in the foreground,

A small stone house on highway 53, 10 miles east of Zuni,
1963-1972

Abandoned stone house with Kwili Yala:we ("Twin Buttes") in the background,

Malapai stone house under construction in the main village,
1963-1978

Adobe bricks used in construction of many Zuni homes,
1963-1978

Cinder block home in Zuni village,
1963-1967

Stone and cinder block home located at the junction of highway 53 and the road going to the south side of the river,
1963-1978

A home my family shared with an elderly Zuni couple when we first moved to Zuni on January 1,
1964

Winters at Zuni,
1964

scopecontent.p: Winters at Zuni can be very cold. On the day we arrived in 1964, the temperature was 10 degrees below zero, and there was ice and snow on the ground

did.unittitle:
100 year-old adobe house behind Kelsey Trading Post,
1964-1965

scopecontent.p: About 9 months after we moved to Zuni, we moved into this 100 year-old adobe house located behind Kelsey Trading Post. Pat Kelsey had offered us the house rent-free. I put in floor joists and a new hardwood floor, and we painted the entire inside of this three-room adobe place that had once been used to house U. S. Cavalry Soldiers.

did.unittitle:
Three-bedroom house behind the Vanderwagen Trading Post,
1965

scopecontent.p: Early in 1965, we moved to this three-bedroom house behind the Vanderwagen Trading Post. The house was graciously offered to us rent-free by Ernie Vanderwagen, owner of the trading post.

did.unittitle:
We found this house to be very comfortable, with propane heat and more space for our family. Today, the house is rented out as a bed and breakfast at Zuni,
1963-1978

In 1972 we moved to this house at Blackrock, where I could have a separate room designated as my study,
1972

Blackrock reservoir,
1963-1978

A series of mud ovens (usually one for each married woman in a household). Zuni sacred mountain in the background,
1968-1973

A Zuni woman with her mud oven under construction,
1968

Ovens built on a raised platform for the convenience of the bread-maker,
1968

Two ovens illustrating that some of the walls of the oven are made of laid-up malapai stone, then coated with mud on the outside,
1968

A fire is built to get the oven hot,
1968-1973

The fire is left to burn for a couple hours,
1968-1972

Then, after the fire is extinguished, the ashes are raked out,
1968-1973

The bottom of the oven is swabbed with water using an evergreen mop,
1968-1973

Meanwhile, white kid (David Cook) and dog wait,
1968-1973

The dough is brought out on boards to be placed in the oven,
1968-1973

Young girls assist,
1968-1973

The bread begins to go into the oven,
1968-1973

Bread being placed in the oven,
1968-1973

Bread being placed into the oven,
1968-1978

Bread in the oven. Sometimes as many as 20 loaves will be baked in the oven at one time,
1968-1973

The door of the oven will be closed using boards and an old coat or blanket to keep the heat in,
1968-1973

After about two hours, the bread is fully baked,
1968-1973

The tasty loaves of bread will go really well with mutton stew,
1968-1973

Fire burning in the oven (extra slide),
1968-1972

Raking out the ashes (extra),
1968-1973

Dowa Yalanne ("corn mountain"), the Zuni sacred mountain,
1965-1973

scopecontent.p: Regarded as sacred because of its prominence in Zuni oral history and because it is the site of sacred religious shrines.

did.unittitle:
Dowa Yalanne in the distance, at mid-day,
1965-1973

Dowa Yalanne, late afternoon,
1965

Dowa Yalanne, as the sun sets,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, in the winter,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, a winter landscape,
1965-1968

Clouds gather over Dowa Yalanne,

Last vestiges of light on Dowa Yalanne before nightfall,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, reflecting the sun on an overcast day,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, framed by a rainbow and hand-hewn rock in the foreground,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, with a rainbow rising above Dimu:shi Yala:we ("arrowhead mountains") to the left and an old fence post in the foreground,
1965-1976

Dowa Yalanne, framed again by an "amidolanne" (rainbow),
1965-1976

Access to the top of Dowa Yalanne is from the east side through a narrow crevice,
1965

On top, there are ruins of an old village, the village of Kwakina,
1965

At the south end of the mountain, many petroglyphs can be seen high on a ledge about 1/3 or the way up,
1965-1976

Aerial view, coming in from the west,
1965-1976

Approaching the south end,
1965-1976

The ancient village of Kwakina (not visible from this shot) is located just above the convergence of cliff walls,
1965-1976

scopecontent.p: The ancient village of Kwakina (not visible from this shot) is located just above the convergence of cliff walls. There are hand and footholds in the steep crevice leading down to a spring, where women descended to collect water and bring it back up to the top.

did.unittitle:
Continuing around the south side, a final view of the top of Dowa Yalanne,
1965-1976

Dirt road to A'laho'ankwi ("red rock place") to the south,
1965-1978

Dirt road leading from Ojo Caliente to the village. The road is referred to as "dalalanaye," or "washboard road,"
1965-1978

Road leading to the village late evening,
1965

Night settles in over the valley,

View of the fields from the top of the water tank mountain,
1965

A winter village scene; privy in foreground,
1965

Flowers blooming in the early spring at Blackrock,

Daffodils in the snow,
1965-1973

Sandstone and limestone reflect the light,

The deep blue sky of Zuni country and mountain shadows,

1965-1972

Winter sunset,

Hish dewutso'ya ("It's beautiful"),

Frosty fields at sunset,
1965-1972

Warm red skies,
1965-1966

A room with a view,
1965-1972

The Creator put us in a beautiful place,
1965-1972

Double rainbow over Blackrock reservoir,
1965-1972

Rainbow over Dimu:shi Yala:we ("Arrowhead Mountains"),
1965-1972

The other end of rainbow #109,
1965-1972

The village in winter,
1965-1972

Ruins of the Zuni Catholic mission, originally built circa 1620,
1965-1972

Catholic mission being renovated,
1968

The renovation almost complete,
1968

Finally completed, the mission is an imposing structure in the heart of old Zuni village, Idiwanakwi ("The Middle Place"),
1968

The Christian Reformed Mission, established in 1897,
1965

Burned to the ground in the spring of 1971,
1965-1971

The Christian Reformed Church and school, rebuilt 1972,
1972

The small Southern Baptist Mission met here from 1967 to 1974, when a new facility was built on the outskirts of the main village,
1967-1972

1965

A Zuni Rainbow Dancer,

Zuni Olla Maidens at Zuni parade,

1965

More Zuni Dancers,
1965

1965

Zuni Tribal Band,

Drummers and singers follow,

More young Zuni Dancers,

An Olla Maiden at the Intertribal Ceremonial,

More Zuni Dancers,

1965

Not given,
1965

Robert Lastyone travels with two horsepower, and one-barrel carburetor,
1965-1969

1965-1970

But the Zuni Fair Queen and her Court ride in style,
1965-1970

Peter Neha, adobe brick maker, and father of fourteen, the dirt to begin the process,
1965-1968

Next he adds water and begins to mix in the straw,
1965-1968

The straw helps to make the bricks stronger and more durable,
1965-1968

Peter is a poor man, but he must mix in enough straw to deliver a quality product,
1965-1968

Having poured the mixture into molds, he now removes the molds and begins to lay out the bricks to dry in the warm sun,
1965-1968

Peter sometimes made as many as two thousand bricks to fill a single order,
1965

It's a big enough task that he needs help, so his mother has joined him,
1965-1972

After the bricks have dried sufficiently, Peter begins to stack them for loading on the customer's pick-up,
1965-1968

More adobe bricks ready to be stacked and loaded,
1965-1968

A few Zuni men raise cattle and graze them on designated grazing allotments on the 440,000-acre reservation,
1965

Other men raise horses,
1965-1972

In the fall of the year or early winter, the Zuni Tribal Stock Pens are alive with activity,
1965-1972

Sheep, a mainstay of the Zuni economy, are brought to the stock pens to be loaded and shipped to market in Albuquerque,
1965-1972

The sheep seem to know what's happening, so it takes some encouragement to get them to go through the chute,
1965-1972

Herded into the loading pen where they are counted and then loaded onto trucks,
1965-1972

In the early to mid-70's there was an Ampex Electronics assembly plant at Blackrock,
1965-1972

The plant employed dozens of Zuni people,
1965-1973

The plant supervisor told me that Zunis do better soldering work than any machine Ampex could develop,
1965-1972

The Zunis, with their skill in working with silver, had just the experience needed to make the plant productive,
1965-1973

Ultimately, the plant closed...,
1965-1973

scopecontent.p: Ultimately, the plant closed, as many of the Zuni employees found that they could make a better living staying at home and doing their work with silver and turquoise. Note: The silver and turquoise craftsmanship of the Zunis is exquisite, and is the primary source of income for most Zuni households. Their pottery work, too, is considered to be among the finest made. For this reason, I have taken the liberty to include some commercially produced slides that illustrate their work (see slide #'s 181-196). These may, or may not, be usable for purposes of the collection.

did.unittitle:
Lorenzo Chavez at about 95-98 years old,
1965-1978

scopecontent.p: Primary language helper in the translation work, and original storyteller of Chummali dap Suski (the Locust and the Coyote) and other stories in the small published book titled Suski.
